timeline.bodyText: The map is an implementation detail, let's only expose the Set<Annotation>.
timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: curious why this change was needed?
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: sorry, that was not intended. will remove it.
replies.author: James201311

replies.bodyText: looks like you forgot to remove it
replies.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: let's make this final, as well as objectDecoders above.
timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: I assume this argument should be @NonNull as well?
timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think we should throw in this case. I might not care about a particular annotation but still want to be able to decode.
A hypothetical example: decode pojo from a firebase function call and save into firestore. the pojo could contain @DocumentId, but functions don't care about it, so they will just ignore it as opposed to failing to decode.
timeline.author: vkryachko
vkryachko

timeline.bodyText:
instead of iterating the types, I suggest you iterate the values, then you don't need to pass the fieldDescriptor to applyFieldModifier().
To get the type of the annotation you can just do annotation.annotationType().
timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: I don't think IllegalArgumentException is appropriate here, it usually indicates that the caller of the library provided some incorrect input. In this case it seems that the only time this could happen is if there is a bug in the library implementation, pls double check if that is the case and if so, change to AssertionError.
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: Great Point here! I totally agree. it should never be null as long as the fieldName have associated FieldRef, in that case, it would make sense to make FieldRef as the key of the fieldDescriptors.
replies.author: James201311

timeline.bodyText: nit: since it only handles annotated fields, would it make sense to name it like AnnotatedFieldHandler?
timeline.author: vkryachko

+import androidx.annotation.Nullable;
+import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
+
+public interface FieldModifier<U extends Annotation> {

timeline.bodyText: I think you can just replace the processor with an inline lambda expression here, wdyt?
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: just tried to place them in an inline lambda expression, but seems like the compiler won’t be able to determine those generic types where we have to cast them multiple times, will use an anonymous class instead.
replies.author: James201311

timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: Instead of copying, consider using Collections.unmodifiableSet(properties.values()), this would prevent modification and avoid a full copy.
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: furthermore, I think it would be even cleaner if you stored the properties above as this.properties = Collections.unmodifiableMap(properties). then you don't need to allocate a new unmodifiableSet here at all, just return properties.values()
replies.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: Worth also noting that annotations themselves need to be annotated with @ExtraProperty
timeline.author: vkryachko

timeline.bodyText: please also change the constructor to this.properties = Collections.unmodifiableMap(properties)
timeline.author: vkryachko

replies.bodyText: the only place called the private constructor is the build method, and Collections.unmodifiableMap(properties) was applied to the properties before passing to the constructor.
replies.author: James201311
